We are working on custom compute engines that have instruction sets that represent the universe of linear algebra. So we have instructions for dot, matvec, matmul, but also cg, bicgstab, cholesky, etc.. Think what Tensilica did for custom instructions in a von Neumann machine, we do for distributed data flow machines.

Would this be the environment/discussion/tutorial in which these approaches to accelerate bottleneck operators could be introduced and expanded?

@xqdan thanks for bringing up the code, supporting customization behavior is important, but I think we still more discussions to pin down the API and how can we document it properly, I will follow up on https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/2030

I think there is some misunderstanding here. To be clear, I did not propose to enumerate all the intrinsics in the pass itself. We just need a formal specification of what this registry is, and how can we design it so that the registry can be used to collect other information about the intrinsic, other than in-place information.

The main danger of this backend hook property is that it is scattered, and one solution to alleviate that is again through a centralized registry like the op registry https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/include/tvm/relay/op.h

To give a concrete example, in our case of operator registry.  Currently, relay's op registry allows us to introduce additional attribute about the intrinsic, for example, you can use the following code to introduce an in-place property later, to a later registered operator property "myexp".

```python
from tvm import relay

relay.op.register("myexp", "TInplace", 1)
```

The key here is: 
- We have a centralized registry to go to when we need certain properties. 
- We have a clear documented list of properties that can be registered and queried by the passes https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/include/tvm/relay/op_attr_types.h
    - This avoids fragmentation of the code and increases the maintainability 

Note that in your case, assume ```cce.copy``` is a target-dependent intrinsic, then this kind of registry satisfies our need.  So far the operator property registry is only introduced in the high-level IR(relay) I am proposing to design a similar one in the low-level IR, for the intrinsics, and use the intrinsic information registry as "backend hook".

Thanks @kun-zh Likely we do not need the field fix_order_args.  The args field before the split follows the order given to the build.  The main question is that during the procedure of split host device, the device function argument code happen in arbitrary order. 

This is not a bug for customized op as long as user directly calls the generate host function. Because the host code still calls into the device code using the correct order. If we want to solve this problem, then we will somehow try to order the arguments in the device code. 

Note that the arguments to the device code does not necessarily corresponds to the host argument(for example, a Buffer in the args could become the data field, or the shape arguments etc). So it is a bit somewhat undefined for the general case.
This is a pretty interesting bug that I can also confirm from my side. I can confirm it on my local machine. interestingly things are fine if we use a small array.

To investigate this a bit further, maybe we could make use of ir builder to build simple functions and run them through LLVM, to see if there is a particular thing that we did wrong.

https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_codegen_vm_basic.py#L37

My guess is there is something wrong with the code we generate(which corrupts the memory) instead of the runtime part, but I am not sure what it is

Should be resolved by https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2070. This bug is caused by a compound of two problems:

- We did not cache the result of packed_func, resulting calls into EnvGetFunc 1m times in the case of 1k * 1k
- We did not lift alloca of the result temporary memory to top of the function, resulting calling alloca 1k * 1k times and stack overflows.


The registry can register functions with certain signature, for example FTVMCompute attribute is a function that can take in context, we will need to carefully design what is the context argument to the function though as it would become part of standard

> @srkreddy1238 are you adding layout trasnform ops into the network? I've also done NCHW -> NHWC conversion for a whole network in the past. My approach was as follows:
> 
> * First, load a standard NCHW layout model from frontend into a nnvm symbol
> * Overwrite "layout" attributes and other layout dependent attribute using [this method](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/nnvm/python/nnvm/_ctypes/symbol.py#L94)
> * Transpose filter weights for NHWC layout
> 
> This way, no in-network layout conversion is necessary and I can operate on NHWC input throughout. This is a kind of hack, but it worked for me.
> 
> In your case, you can overwrite all NHWC layout attributes, run NCHW network as usual, and then convert the output to NHWC if necessary.

Could you expain more detail? I want to know a little more how to do it use your mentioned method, for example Reshape op.

@srkreddy1238 maybe a little out dated. But I want to raise my concern. In your implementation like convolution, you will transpose NHWC to NCHW, then call NCHWs version of conv2d, finally back to NHWC using transpose. Do you consider the performance and costing time of transpose? My test of mobilenet 1st layer, convolution is 2ms, but transpose time will be 1ms, which can not be acceptable in performances view. Especially we have so many conv2d in one model.

@Ravenwater this issue is around the specific aspect of using micro-asm kernels. Your proposal seems to be bigger and could be related to the general high level IR in tvm, and we would love to see contributions on that front as well

@tqchen I see, I am looking for the interfaces that define the abstract hardware instructions of the execution engine. In our hardware, we separate the memory access patterns from the computation so that we can build memory streams that have optimal system resource utilization and performance properties. The hw has a coarse data flow command packet semantic, which when mapped against the IR is likely to collapse many nodes into a single instruction. If you can point me to the right interfaces, we can explore how to contribute our high-performance data flow hardware.

@tqchen Sure, the arguments doesn't need to be ordered because the host code which TVM generated can call the device code correctly. But If I only want use TVM as a standalone DSL compiler to generate device code , then use the other runtime framework to call it,  the framework should know the argument order in device function. We want to integrated TVM compiler into the other runtime framework automatically, only let user define the argument list in their DSL code. @Zaihua-Zhou

Here are the changes I made in an effort to share as much code as possible between the caffe2 and onnx frontends:

- Move common util functions `dimension_picker, dimension_constraint, infer_channels, revert_caffe2_pad` into a separate file `onnx_caffe2_utils.py`
- Reuse onnx converters for `Add, Sum, Softmax`. We can add more ops to this list if needed

I kept `Caffe2OpConverter` because caffe2 does not have the version problem.

@xqdan to follow up on this. I think we should have a global centralized registry attributes where all the backend can register on. 

- For backend specific intrinsics, there should be no naming conflict(e.g. use cuda prefix for cuda only intrinsics). If an intrinsic shares name among backends, that should really mean they need to have similar behavior. We can still get backend specific behavior by having a target aware dispatcher for common names.
- It is true that a single function might be able to cover multiple intrinsic, in that case, just register it for each intrinsic is not redundant, note that the function is only defined once.
- We can enable any arguments to the registered function, but should really be careful about the choice and document it properly

Lint failed due to 

```
C:131, 0: Function name "convolution_inference_without_weight_transform" doesn't conform to '[a-z_][a-z0-9_]{2,30}$' pattern (invalid-name)

C:183, 0: Function name "convolution_inference_weight_transform" doesn't conform to '[a-z_][a-z0-9_]{2,30}$' pattern (invalid-name)
```

being too long (38 characters). Does anyone have suggestions for name changes or should we ignore the lint? I was following the convention from https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/9f441d817c7e3c5eeeb0078c5c60701a6e7ba33b/topi/python/topi/arm_cpu/conv2d.py#L495-L497, etc.

Note that the NNPACK bindings here wouldn't have actually compiled for about a year (since https://github.com/Maratyszcza/NNPACK/commit/65d0626b3234aa2e50a439360359dfc5ed642bcd), so I think a good follow up (that I could take) would be adding `set(USE_NNPACK ON)` + `test_nnpack.py` to the CPU CIs.

One thing I'm curious about - have you considered instead (or in addition) adding an option for generating code for LLVM backends with address sanitizer? It seems pretty simple to add (https://github.com/halide/Halide/blob/1d471591077939fda9d9cbb77f92c6322cf28206/src/CodeGen_LLVM.cpp#L1094-L1104), and would catch these OOB accesses, along with a lot more kinds of bugs (https://clang.llvm.org/docs/AddressSanitizer.html). 

I noticed you've contributed to LLVM's sanitizers in the past, so I wonder if you agree this is useful here?

This looks good to me correctness/code-reuse wise - and this also paves the way for allowing importing C2 int8 graphs (used by e.g. FBGEMM/QNNPACK/BoltNN HVX) into TVM. I think this is a useful addition to the TVM project.

Thanks, @ajtulloch this is merged.  For CI, we are using a CI image that is relatively stable, please send in update to the CI docker as a separate PR, then I will update the image and we can add the test case.

In the meanwhile, it is still worth to improve the 3x3 ops with tensorizations just as a alternative and see how far we can get through AutoTVM

While the current PR is enough for this case, let us try to push the centralized attribute registry instead, for the following reasons:

- We will need a centralized place to document and use these intrinsic attribute, the hook function is a bit hidden and harder for new developers to get started
- It is sometimes helpful to have a per intrinsic behavior and specifically enumerate these behaviors in a sensible fashion.
- The backend implementation of checking can be reused across multiple locations.

To elaborate, if we expect there is going to be a lot of customizable behaviors via backend hook function, the concern is not only how to enable what we want, but how to maintain these attributes in a way that every developer can understand and hack on.
I see. I can act on this.
